Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Comparative genomics of SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility and immune defense in mammals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to compare genomes of hundreds of mammal species, finding differences in DNA that distinguish species resistant to SARS-CoV-2 from those that are very susceptible. This information is needed to understand how the current SARS-CoV-2 virus spread to humans and to identify potential host animals (e.g., pet, livestock, and pest species) that may be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 in the USA. SARS-CoV-2, the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic, can infect diverse species of animals. There is a variation in susceptibility to and severity of disease between species. This variation suggests that some species have genetic differences that dictate susceptibility to COVID-19. This work will identify how coronaviruses adapt to new host species, information that will help predict and control future coronavirus outbreaks. Funding will support training a graduate student in research, thereby training the next generation of the bioeconomy workforce.

This project will investigate how the host genome shapes host-pathogen interactions, and how coronaviruses like SARS-CoV-2 evolve to exploit new hosts. The researchers will compare existing genomic data for hundreds of mammals using three complementary approaches: (1) Measure structural and sequence homology in two host proteins, ACE2 and TMPRSS2, necessary for infection in humans; (2) Analyze existing RNA-seq datasets to (a) identify species with co-expression of ACE2 and TMPRSS2, and potentially other proteases implicated in infection, in the same tissue, and (b) search for incidental coronaviral sequence data from diverse mammalian species; (3) Test for variants in evolutionarily conserved elements that are correlated with species susceptibility, using forward genomics. With these analyses, the researchers will identify species with potential as reservoirs for SARS-CoV-2 viral spillback into humans, and those that are promising systems for investigating SARS-CoV-2 evolution, host defenses, and host-pathogen interactions. This RAPID award is made by the Physiological and Structural Systems Cluster in the BIO Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We compared DNA sequences to identify mammalian species that may be at high risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, the coronavirus that causes Covid-19. Even with global vaccination campaigns now underway, infection in other species could seed new Covid-19 outbreaks among people who do not have enduring immunity. Moreover, infection with SARS-CoV-2 could increase risk of extinction for threatened or endangered species. Transmission from humans into captive animals has already been observed for several other species, including mink and tiger, and knowing which species at risk could inform measures to protect humans and other species alike.

We reasoned that infection risk could be especially high for species for which the DNA sequences of two genes --- ACE2 and TMPRSS2 genes, which encode proteins that the SARS-CoV-2 virus uses as a doorway into human cells --- are very similar to human. We found that nearly all mammals have both of these proteins on the surface of their lung and kidney cells. While the TMPRSS2 protein itself is nearly identical across most mammals, ACE2 varies among them, with some species almost identical to human, and others more dissimilar. Comparing ACE2 proteins between human and the ~400 other species in our study set of infection, we identified nearly 80 at high risk of infection, including gorilla and white-tailed deer. We also screened species for evidence of contemporary or historical infection with coronaviruses, which could suggest which species may have acted as intermediate hosts prior to SARS-CoV-2 infecting human populations. 


Our project yielded several immediate, actionable insights. Veterinarians at zoos throughout the US used our list of high-risk species to identify those for which zookeepers would need to follow the highest standards of protective equipment while caring for animals, especially those from threatened and endangered species. Zookeepers also restricted public access to petting zoos that host animals we predicted to be at high risk. Our work has also been used by scientists looking for better animal models for studying SARS-CoV-2 infection, and scientists modelling the risk of future outbreaks.  


Our findings have also led to new questions we are now working to answer. We scored mink as "low risk" for SARS-CoV-2 infection, based on its ACE2 gene sequence, but mink have been infected at very high numbers at fur farms.  We are now testing whether, in mink, genes other than ACE2 are used by SARS-CoV-2 to enter cells, a finding that could reveal other at-risk species.
